attributes.mlflow.spanInputs:
{"query": "What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?", "context": [{"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "c9e1e39a-b35a-411e-99ad-8a3f1a0f4159", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "6d92aaa7-76f4-4933-96d2-dfedf1fdfa01", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "375c5a8a-f28f-4712-b101-6f8b19d8dc2e", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/integrating-sagemaker.md", "_id": "659b9fdc-f9d5-40d6-a6f1-a752e2b955a4", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.", "type": "Document"}]}
attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"result": "AWS SageMaker's geospatial capabilities refer to the features and services in SageMaker that allow you to perform geospatial data processing and analysis. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker, meaning they are services that you can use without having to manage the underlying hardware. However, they can only perform operations that you, as the user, permit.

To use these geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. The user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what you can do within AWS. The execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants SageMaker permission to access your AWS resources. This execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy, which specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, is a policy that you can attach to an execution role to grant it permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with 'SageMaker', 'Sagemaker', 'sagemaker', or 'aws-glue' in the name. If you need more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs using other sections of the guide.

In summary, SageMaker's geospatial capabilities are a set of managed services that allow you to process and analyze geospatial data, which require appropriate user and execution roles for access."}

attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"output_text": "AWS SageMaker's geospatial capabilities refer to the features and services in SageMaker that allow you to perform geospatial data processing and analysis. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker, meaning they are services that you can use without having to manage the underlying hardware. However, they can only perform operations that you, as the user, permit.

To use these geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. The user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what you can do within AWS. The execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants SageMaker permission to access your AWS resources. This execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy, which specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, is a policy that you can attach to an execution role to grant it permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with 'SageMaker', 'Sagemaker', 'sagemaker', or 'aws-glue' in the name. If you need more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs using other sections of the guide.

In summary, SageMaker's geospatial capabilities are a set of managed services that allow you to process and analyze geospatial data, which require appropriate user and execution roles for access."}

attributes.mlflow.spanInputs:
{"question": "What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?", "context": "SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.

Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.

How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide."}
attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"text": "AWS SageMaker's geospatial capabilities refer to the features and services in SageMaker that allow you to perform geospatial data processing and analysis. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker, meaning they are services that you can use without having to manage the underlying hardware. However, they can only perform operations that you, as the user, permit.

To use these geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. The user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what you can do within AWS. The execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants SageMaker permission to access your AWS resources. This execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy, which specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, is a policy that you can attach to an execution role to grant it permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with 'SageMaker', 'Sagemaker', 'sagemaker', or 'aws-glue' in the name. If you need more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs using other sections of the guide.

In summary, SageMaker's geospatial capabilities are a set of managed services that allow you to process and analyze geospatial data, which require appropriate user and execution roles for access."}

Prompt after formatting:
[32;1m[1;3m
<|begin_of_text|>
<|start_header_id|>system<|end_header_id|> 
You are an AI assistant that helps users with answering queries about documentation. You have access to a large collection of documents 
from AWS documentation, particularly SageMaker and have to answer in details and explain clearly.
 <|eot_id|>
<|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|> 
Please answer my question about AWS documentation only based on provided context.


-----------
This is the context:
SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.

Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.

How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.

-----------
This is the question:
What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?

Create an execution role", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "6d92aaa7-76f4-4933-96d2-dfedf1fdfa01", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "375c5a8a-f28f-4712-b101-6f8b19d8dc2e", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/integrating-sagemaker.md", "_id": "659b9fdc-f9d5-40d6-a6f1-a752e2b955a4", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.", "type": "Document"}]}
response:
{"result": "AWS SageMaker's geospatial capabilities refer to the features and services in SageMaker that allow you to perform geospatial data processing and analysis. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker, meaning they are services that you can use without having to manage the underlying hardware. However, they can only perform operations that you, as the user, permit.

To use these geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. The user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what you can do within AWS. The execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants SageMaker permission to access your AWS resources. This execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy, which specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, is a policy that you can attach to an execution role to grant it permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with 'SageMaker', 'Sagemaker', 'sagemaker', or 'aws-glue' in the name. If you need more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs using other sections of the guide.

In summary, SageMaker's geospatial capabilities are a set of managed services that allow you to process and analyze geospatial data, which require appropriate user and execution roles for access."}
